dialogue_content.speaker: Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: I'd love to hear about the Great Storm, Lars.

dialogue_content.original_text: It was back in '63, a night I'll never forget.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I was just a young lad, about 15, working on my father's boat.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: We were out in the North Sea, and the waves... they were monstrous.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I remember gripping onto the rigging for dear life, praying we'd make it back to shore.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That must have been hard, gripping onto the rigging like that at such a young age. It sounds like you had quite the experience with the sea early on. So when did things change for you, when did you decide to buy your own boat?

dialogue_content.original_text: It was around the late '70s, and I had saved up every penny I could get my hands on.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I was in my thirties when I finally got enough to buy my own boat.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: That sounds like an incredible journey, Lars. So, with your own boat, when did things take a turn with the overfishing regulations?

dialogue_content.original_text: It's heartbreaking to see the industry shrink like this, but I suppose we have to respect the ocean if we want it to last.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
Interviewer
dialogue_content.text: It must be hard to see such changes. How do you spend your days now that you're not out on the water as much?

dialogue_content.original_text: I still go down to the harbor every morning to watch the sunrise.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject

dialogue_content.original_text: I mend nets for the younger lads sometimes, share a story or two.
dialogue_content.speaker: Subject
